title: 103_hr4858
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. The amendment specifies that an issuer whose securities are solely owned by qualified purchasers will be considered an investment company for certain purposes. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. An issuer whose securities are solely owned by qualified purchasers will be considered an investment company for certain purposes. SEC. 4 defines a qualified purchaser. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person owning at least $10,000,000 in securities or a person owning and investing at least $100,000,000 in securities on a discretionary basis. The Commission may determine that certain individuals with a high level of financial sophistication, significant net worth, substantial assets, relationships with issuers, or other relevant factors do not require the protections of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission has the authority to establish rules and regulations regarding this determination. The Commission has the authority to adopt rules and regulations for specified individuals to protect investors and serve the public interest. SEC. 5 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine investment securities. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph allowing companies not issuing redeemable securities, regulated by the state, and focused on promoting economic development through financial or managerial assistance. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to conduct business activities and sell securities to accredited investors or other approved persons. At least 80 percent of the securities sold must be held by individuals residing or having a substantial business presence in that state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to sell securities to accredited investors or approved persons as permitted by the Commission. The company cannot purchase securities issued by investment companies, except for certain exclusions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to invest at least 65 percent of their assets in specific securities or comparable ones. Companies relying on this exemption must comply with certain provisions and file with the Commission. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to invest at least 65 percent of their assets in specific securities or comparable ones. Companies meeting the requirements can rely on the exemption by filing a notification with the Commission. The exemption may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to increase the exemption amount to $10,000,000 or as determined by the Commission. SEC. 8 defines an eligible portfolio company. SEC. 8 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to define an eligible portfolio company with specific asset and capital requirements. SEC. 9 amends the definition of a business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940, specifying exceptions for providing managerial assistance. SEC. 10 addresses the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 regarding the acquisition of assets by business development companies, allowing for acquisitions from any person subject to SEC regulations. SEC. 11 amends the Act by including "and capital structure" after "portfolio" in written statements.
